instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00244: What is 820-00244? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.R6990: What is R6990? Resistor between charger voltage and input to PP3V42_G3H power supply on Macbooks from around the year 2012. This resistor blows when C6990 has shorted to ground or U6990 has shorted to ground, and will result in PP3V42_G3H missing and the magsafe charger not having a light since PP3V42_G3H is necessary for the SMC to turn on and the onewire circuit to turn on..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Hey Rossmann Team,

I have a Problem with <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Logicboard.
I dindt have any sign of life. no current on USB-Ports.
So i decided to change the <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>.
Now i have a low current. (0.025A) for few seconds and then 0,0.

Cause the missing <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> i changed <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>

but it doesnt make any difference.

<SIGNAL>P_IN</SIGNAL>:           5,19V
<SIGNAL>SMC_RST_IN</SIGNAL>:    0 V
VDDA/P:          5 V
 <SIGNAL>SMC_RST</SIGNAL>:  0.6 V
A/BMON:    0V

Thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Remove F7040 and check <CAPACITOR>C7043</CAPACITOR> voltage.

Do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> at least?

threads.message:
I did. = 0V

sadly no Voltage on <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Input voltage can't switch to 20V without <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>.
SMC must talk with <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chip and this voltage is required.
Post its diode mode to ground reading.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: you need all readings ? from <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> ?

threads.message: [ATTACH type="full"]61324[/ATTACH]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: I meant <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> reading to ground, in diode mode.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Well at least you have all diode readings of the <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> now.
<SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> have 360

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Yeah, but I prefer to get the readings on the interesting lines; instead of looking of that screenshot.
Like the LDOs lines of <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>, for example.

You've posted some signals and voltage for <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>, but we need more; ACIN, <SIGNAL>VR_AON</SIGNAL>, ACOK, <SIGNAL>LDO_3</SIGNAL>/5P0.
If any missing, check it in diode mode too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
"ACIN:  5.19V"
Looks like <RESISTOR>R7011</RESISTOR> is bad; change it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Check diode mode to ground at <SIGNAL>3V3R3V0_AON</SIGNAL>; compare with good board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Having 3V there doesn't assure all is good.
Lower diode mode reading than expected, may be caused by a bad component in that line.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
[URL unfurl="true"]https://openboarddata.org/?a=showboardsolutions&bpath=laptops/apple/<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>[/URL]

<SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is generated by <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>.
The chip may bad, or has bad solders.Just in case, check/replace <RESISTOR>R6990</RESISTOR> and R/<CAPACITOR>C6994</CAPACITOR>.
Be sure all traces are good.
